
### pqqp

![pqqp](https://github.com/Hed6eH0g/ctf/blob/main/2023/wanictf/crypto/pqqp/pqqp_0.png)


This challenge gave us information concerning $n, e, c$, and $s = p^q + q^p \pmod{n}$.
Interestingly, $s$ is equivalent to $s = p^q + q^p = p + q \pmod{n}$ as you can check as follows.
```
def test(p, q):
  n = p * q
  print(f'{p}^{q} mod {n} = {pow(p, q, n)}')
  print(f'{q}^{p} mod {n} = {pow(q, p, n)}')
  print('')

test(3, 5)
test(3, 7)
test(3, 11)
test(3, 13)
test(3, 17)
test(3, 19)
 
test(5, 7)
test(5, 11)
test(5, 13)
test(5, 17)
test(5, 19)
 
test(7, 11)
test(5, 13)
test(5, 17)
test(5, 19)
 
test(11, 13)
test(5, 17)
test(5, 19)
 
test(13, 17)
test(5, 19)
 
test(17, 19)
```

Since we can compute the secret key $d$ if we have $\phi(n) = (p-1)(q-1)$, we can guess that a clue for given $s$ would be there.  
By expanding $phi(n)$ as $phi(n) = pq - (p+q) + 1 = n - s + 1$, it is found that $phi(n)$ can be available with $n$ and $s$.
Therefore, the flag is recovered with the following code. 

```
n = 
e = 65537
c = 
s = 

import libnum
from Crypto.Util.number import long_to_bytes

phi = n - s + 1
d = libnum.invmod(e, phi)
m = pow(c, d, n)
print(long_to_bytes(m))
```
